p.s: Today I'm going to inform you about the problems in the the textile industry.

To do that, I've informed myself on the internet, and one of my sources as ana germanGerman interview with a woman called Imke Müller-Hellmann was called Fast Fashion: Unser Kleiderkonsum ist Wahnsinn, which was produced by Jörg Oberwittler in December 2017 and published in Spiegel Online.
The interview is about a woman who got curious about where her clothes were made and who made them so she flew to Bangladesh to solve this question.
She said that the most shocking experience was, seeing the river Buriganga, the river was pitchblackpitch black and of plastic.

She also reports about horrible shifts, some workers worked 10 to 12 hour shifts and when they're lucky only six Daysdays a week, she descripesdescribes their work as very monotonmonotone or rather boring.
Imke Müller-Hellmann says that boycotting Bangladesh clothing or textile products in general isn't the solution.

80% of goods from Bangladesh are textile goods, so the people would become even poorer, instead we should put pressure on the big brands and industries to guranteeguarantee better and safer working conditions, but also a higher wage.
In Generalgeneral she thinks that the politics should become activactive as well and don't let the market decide over Billionsbillions people lives.
